webTitle: Fed insists economy can withstand stimulus cut despite rising prices

fields.standfirst:
• Central bank to cut bond-buying stimulus by $10bn a month
• Upbeat Fed tone at odds with the economists' forecasts
fields.body:
The Federal Reserve insisted that the US economy is strong enough to withstand a cut to its stimulus program, despite being forced once again to cut its growth forecasts.

In its updated economic forecast on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve's picture of the US economy remained chipper, even as consumers find their wallets emptier and analysts widely agreed that "the facts are now different" about the prospects for US economic growth.

“Information received since … April indicates that growth in economic activity has rebounded in recent months,” the Federal Reserve said in a statement on Wednesday.

“The committee expects that, with appropriate policy accommodation, economic activity will expand at a moderate pace and labor market conditions will continue to improve gradually.”

The Fed statement was nearly an exact copy of its last statement, despite the expectations of economists that the central bank would recognize recent weaknesses in unemployment and GDP. On inflation, the Fed said it is "monitoring inflation developments carefully", but did not commit to any action.

It cut its bond purchases by $10bn a month, in a continuing effort to exit its quantitative easing program.

The upbeat tone of the Fed is strongly at odds with the view of many economists that measures of the economy have grown more troubling since April. Specifically, gross domestic product has fallen into negative territory, indicating that the economy shrank, and unemployment remains high.

The Fed's chairman, Janet Yellen, struck a largely optimistic note in her press conference, saying there are reasons "why we should see sustained growth above the economy's potential," including rising home prices and an improving global economy.

That may be some time in the future, however, as she conceded early on that "the potential growth of the economy may be lower for some time."

Yellen also indicated she is unconcerned about inflation, in answer to a question about whether the Fed is taking an overly rosy view and "behind the curve" on inflation.

"The data we're seeing is noisy … inflation is rising in line with committee's expectations," Yellen said.

Yellen also suggested that interest rates would stay low "for a considerable period" after the Fed's bond-buying program ends.

Economists had widely expected the Fed to revise its GDP expectations downward along with its expectations for the unemployment rate.

As Lindsey Group analyst Peter Boockvar wrote to clients before Wednesday's meeting: "[The Federal Reserve’s] credibility is on the line if they ignore that the facts are now different."

The worsening of the economy has been evident to many Americans. Unemployment statistics show that only 62% of people are working, and houses prices have stayed high while mortgage lending is unavailable to most people.

The biggest concern at the moment is inflation, which is punishing families. The prices that consumers are paying for day-to-day food and gas are rising. The inflation index for food prices is at its highest point in nearly three years.

Meat prices, for instance, are up 7.7% and dairy prices are up 4.2%, according to Keefe Bruyette & Woods. The pressure of paying more at the supermarket combines with rising household debt and falling wages to mean that households are being squeezed between paying off their debt and shelling out rising prices for necessities – all while their incomes remain stagnant.

"May was not a good month for consumers’ wallets," said Michael Montgomery of IHS Global Insight. “The energy portion of consumers’ budgets was stretched by higher gasoline and electricity bills. It was no joy to go to the food store either.”

Montgomery added: “The twin gains in food and gasoline are particularly disquieting to consumers as those are the two most often seen prices, and therefore the ones which affect moods the most … This is not the stuff of hyper- or even double-digit inflation, but it is draining and seemingly just one thing after another.”

For the past several years, the Federal Reserve has issued positive forecasts for US growth, expecting a recovery.

Yet many consumers have been feeling the pinch in a way that the central bank has not anticipated. Unemployment has remained high, housing weak, inflation rising and growth slow. The Fed’s expectations for GDP - which measures the overall productivity of the economy - have already proven incorrect. Policymakers expected 2.8% to 3% growth, while the most recent reading was -1% if considered over a year.

The Fed most recently expected the unemployment rate to fall to the range of 6.1 to 6.3% by the end of the year.

It's already there, as Boockvar notes, with two straight months of 6.3% unemployment. The labor force participation rate, which measures how many working-age adults actually have jobs, is 62.8% - one of the lowest percentages in 30 years.

The housing market has been struggling more than the Fed expected, with expert Robert Shiller calling the trends "worrisome." "The spring home selling season has been mixed at best as investors have slowed down their purchase pace and the first time potential home buyer has been more inclined to rent," Boockvar wrote.


Another thorny problem facing the Federal Reserve has been interest rates, which Wall Street wants to rise after several years at zero. Worsening economic conditions are likely to keep rates low, economists say.

fields.standfirst:
• US central bank cuts bond-buying program by $10bn a month
  • But Fed slashes growth projections for US economy
  • Central bank insists economic recovery is still on track
  • Earlier: Bank of England moves closer to raising rates, but not yet
fields.body:
9.36pm BST

Wrapping up

The Fed sharply cut its growth rates but continued tapering its bond-buying program, cutting it back to $35bn a month. Get the full story from the Guardian US economics editor Heidi Moore (@moorehn).

9.36pm BST

Following the Fed announcement markets closed up Wednesday. The Dow Jones Industrial closed up 95 points and 0.58%, the Nasdaq is up 25 points and 0.59%, and the S&P 500 is up almost 15 points and 0.77%.

8.48pm BST

Analysts are reacting to Yellen's steady-as-she-goes tapering and interest rate announcements.

Updated at 8.54pm BST

8.42pm BST

A full transcript of Yellen's speech is now available.

8.35pm BST

Want the full analysis of the feds announcement today? Check out the story by Guardian US economics editor Heidi Moore.

8.29pm BST

The Federal Reserve press conference just ended.

8.26pm BST

Now, a reporter asks how wages might grow over the next year.

Yellen says right now it's flat, at 2%, and that it's likely to grow when there's less slack in labor market.

My own expectation is that as the labor market begins to tighten, we will see wage growth pick up some to the point where real wage growth, where compensation or nominal wages are rising more rapidly than inflation, so households are getting a real increase in their take-home pay," Yellen said.

8.22pm BST

Pedro da Costa (@pdacosta)of Dow Jones News Wires asks about the brewing conflict in Iraq and other global instability. Can the US be a, "lone engine of economic" growth globally?

Broadly speaking, if the question is to what extent is monetary policy at this time being driven by financial stability concerns, I would say that while I would never take off the table that monetary policy should – could, in some circumstances, respond, I don't see them shaping monetary policy in an important way right now," says Yellen.

8.16pm BST

Bloomberg TV and radio reporter Michael McKee (@mckonomy) asks how the Fed can keep from appearing to fall behind when it uses lagging indicators such as employment and inflation.

"We are very attentive to unfolding economic developments," said Yellen, and said she's committed to communicating that to the public, holding additional press conferences if necessary.

8.11pm BST

When the Federal Reserve chair says the recession could have caused permanent damage, it doesn't go unnoticed.

8.07pm BST

Benyamin Appelbaum (@BCAppelbaum) asks how much monetary policy can change problems such as nagging unemployment. Yellen said there could be some "permanent damage" done by long-term unemployment.

"My hope would be, and my expectation is, that as the economy recovers, we will see some repair of that, that many of those individuals who were long-term unemployed or those who are now counted as out of the labor force would take jobs if the economy is stronger and would be drawn back in again. But it is conceivable that there's some permanent damage thereto, to them, to their own well-being, their family's well-being, and the economy's potential," said Yellen.

8.07pm BST

Now, here's a question about the "dot plot." Here's an explanation of how dot plots show interest rates by Business Insider.

And a little dot plot humor below.

8.07pm BST

"It's true that unemployment has declined by more than the committee expected," said Yellen. Says the labor market has "continued to broadly improve."

However, she says that a portion of the decline in unemployment rate reflects a kind of "shadow unemployment or discouragement" for workers, and possibly demographics.

8.03pm BST

Here's a great graphic on inflation measures.

Updated at 8.06pm BST

8.03pm BST

A CNBC reporter asks if the Federal Reserve isn't "behind the curve" on inflation, referencing a 2.1% consumer price index (CPI). Yellen says the data we're seeing is "noisy."

Personal consumer expenditure, or PCE, is what the Fed uses to measure inflation. That's at 1.42%.

Updated at 8.06pm BST

7.43pm BST

Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen says that interest rates will likely remain low, even after the Reserve's asset buying program ends.

Based on its current assessment of these factors, the committee anticipates that it likely will be appropriate to maintain the current target range for the federal funds rate for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends, especially if projected inflation continues to run below the Committee's 2% longer-run goal and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored," Yellen said.

7.43pm BST

The FOMC expects that inflation will fall back down to 2%, according to Yellen. Right now it's at 2.1%.

7.38pm BST

Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen has begun her press conference now. She concedes GDP is "down notably" from the March projections, to 2.1% to 2.3%, Yellen says, mostly because of the "unexpected contractions" in the first quarter.

7.37pm BST

The open markets committee expects to continue winding down the bond-buying program. Most expect the Fed will end it in October.

The central bank left open the door to adjusting the program however.

This assessment will take into account a wide range of information, including measures of labor market conditions, indicators of inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and readings on financial developments.

7.27pm BST

The Federal Reserve saw further improvement in markets, it said in a press release.

Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in April indicates that growth in economic activity has rebounded in recent months. Labor market indicators generally showed further improvement. The unemployment rate, though lower, remains elevated. Household spending appears to be rising moderately and business fixed investment resumed its advance, while the recovery in the housing sector remained slow. Fiscal policy is restraining economic growth, although the extent of restraint is diminishing. Inflation has been running below the Committee's longer-run objective, but longer-term inflation expectations have remained stable.

Not all analysts agree though.

7.16pm BST

More specifically about the taper – the Federal Reserve plans to buy $15bn worth of mortgage backed securities per month, and $20bn in treasury bonds each month, reducing each by $5bn.

7.15pm BST

Despite saying that the economy was strong enough to reduce the stimulus, the Fed also slashed its projections for US growth. In March, the central bank projected US GDP growth at 2.8% to 3%. The bank now believes the economy will grow between 2.1% and 2.3%. Read the full statement here.

6.50pm BST

Fed cuts stimulus by $10bn

The Federal Open Markets Committee announces, as expected, that it is continuing to wind down, or "taper" its bond-buying program known as quantitative easing.

It said there was was "sufficient underlying strength" in the US economy to reduce the stimulus program by $10bn. The Fed will start buying $35bn per month in bonds and mortgage backed securities in July, instead of $45bn.

Updated at 7.13pm BST

6.44pm BST

What to expect today

Here's Guardian US economics editor Heidi Moore's primer on what to expect from Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen's 2pm press conference.

This meeting will be the one where the Federal Reserve will have to prove it's connected to reality. Its forecasts have been relatively chipper - or at least optimistic - through five years of a slow recovery. Now the tides seem be turning, and the recovery looks threatened. As Lindsey Group analyst Peter Boockvar wrote to clients today, "their credibility is on the line if they ignore that the facts are now different."

What facts? Here's what observers are watching.

GDP: Expect the Fed to cut its estimates. The Fed's estimates for GDP - which measures the overall productivity of the economy - were on the high side for 2014, with expectations of 2.8% to 3% growth. The actual latest growth figure is far, far below that: it's -1%. Being off by a few percentage points is a big issue for the Fed's credibility -- though to be fair, it's used to being wrong. Still, look for the Fed to join the reality-based community by cutting its forecasts for economic growth.

Unemployment: Expect the Fed to cut its estimates. The Fed most recently expected the unemployment rate to fall to the range of 6.1 to 6.3% by the end of the year. It's already there, as Boockvar notes, with two straight months of 6.3% unemployment. but it doesn't tell the whole story. The reason the unemployment rate is falling is because more people are becoming disillusioned and dropping out of the workforce. The best measure of that dropout trend is called the the labor force participation rate, and it measures how many working-age adults actually have jobs. At the moment, it's 62.8% - one of the lowest percentages in 30 years.

Inflation: Watch how the Fed interprets the data. After years of bafflement over why inflation remained so low, inflation is rising for consumers far faster than the Fed expected. The real-world measure of inflation, which is called the Consumer Price Index or CPI, is now at about 2% - far above the 1.7% that the Fed predicted in April.

Housing: Watch how the Fed interprets the data. The housing market has been struggling more than the Fed expected, with expert Robert Shiller calling the trends "worrisome." The rise in housing prices is supposed to make consumers feel rich enough to spend more money, but it's not accomplishing that. "The spring home selling season has been mixed at best as investors have slowed down their purchase pace and the first time potential home buyer has been more inclined to rent," Boockvar wrote.

Interest rates: The Federal Reserve's job is to manage interest rates, and investors have been waiting years for an increase in rates; they argue that low rates have been hurting savings. The Fed has indicated it won't raise interest rates until 2015 or later. With the economic picture worsening, however, it may be under pressure.

Overall: Expect a "nothing to see here, folks," stance that will require a deeper interpretation of how the Fed is seeing the economy. Fed officials will probably try to make this week’s FOMC meeting uneventful for markets, continuing to sound positive about the outlook," said economists at High-Frequency Economics.

Updated at 6.44pm BST

6.09pm BST

My colleague Jessica Glenza will take this live blog over before the Fed's announcement, at 2pm EST. Goodbye from London. GW

5.40pm BST

Federal Reserve decision on tapering, and Janet Yellen's press conference, loom

It's now less than 90 minute until the Federal Reserve announces the conclusions of this week's monetary policy meeting, followed by Janet Yellen's second press conference since succeeding Ben Bernanke.

The FOMC announcement comes at 2pm New York time, with the press conference at 2.30pm.

Wall Street will be looking for several different things. For example:

1) Did the Fed keep tapering? - it's expected to lop another $10bn off it bond-buying stimulus programme.

2) The new economic forecasts. Will the Fed follow the IMF's lead and cut its forecast for growth this year, now it's seen that the economy shrank a little over the winter.

3) And what will Yellen say about inflation - which rose unexpectedly to an annual rate of 2.1% last month - and job creation?

Reporters will want to know how she thinks interest rates could return to more normal levels.

4) We get the Fed's famous/notorious dot chart - showing where policy-setters believe interest rates will be in the medium term.

And heres are some handy charts showing US inflation, from Nomura.

Updated at 5.45pm BST

5.26pm BST

FT: IMF to push for eurozone QE tomorrow

Interesting.. the FT's Peter Speigel is reporting that the International Monetary Fund will tomorrow recommend that the eurozone considers a US-style quantitative easing programme to ward off deflation.

Here's a flavour:

The IMF evaluation, to be presented by managing director Christine Lagarde to eurozone finance ministers on Thursday in Luxembourg, credits the EU with taking “strong policy action” that “laid the foundations for recovery” after the eurozone crisis. But it also concludes that both debt levels and unemployment remain too high and could impair a return to “robust” growth.

While the fund welcomes recent measures adopted by the ECB, which earlier this month took the unprecedented step of cutting one of its key interest rates below zero and offering up to €400bn in cheap loans to banks who agree to lend to small businesses, it suggests they may not be enough.

The draft IMF statement finds that eurozone “inflation is worryingly low, including in the core countries”, stifling demand and growth. If prices continue to rise slowly, the IMF argues, the ECB should consider following the US Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and the Bank of England by purchasing sovereign bonds.

“If inflation remains stubbornly low, the ECB should consider a large-scale asset purchase programme, primarily of sovereign assets according to the ECB’s capital key,” the statement reads. “This would boost confidence, improve corporate and household balance sheets, and stimulate bank lending.

More here: IMF calls on ECB to consider quantitative easing to stimulate growth

It's not the first time the IMF has pushed for more unconventional monetary policy - Lagarde talked about QE in April too. But it will intensify pressure on the ECB to ease policy.

5.11pm BST

Over in the eurozone, Cyprus has held a successful bond auction today - selling more debt than initially planned.

Cyprus found buyers for €750m of five-year bonds, up from a target of €500m, at a yield of reportedly around 4.85%.

Finance minister Harris Georgiades told reporters that the move was an important step towards eventually returning to the financial markets after its bailout, which began 15 months ago.

"This issue means that we will be able to refinance a significant part of the present domestic debt and achieving a lower debt re-servicing cost"

4.53pm BST

Oh, and the session is still viewable on the Parliament Live site.

4.46pm BST

To recap - highlights of Kristin Forbes' appearance before MPs ahead of joining the Bank of England start here:

And her warning about 'sanguine' bond investors taking risks is here.

4.38pm BST

Peter Spence of City AM has the story on how Kristin Forbes defended using the inflation rate as the main target for the Bank of England, rather than nominal GDP:

Here's why new Bank of England staffer Kristin Forbes is defending inflation targeting

4.20pm BST

Incoming MPC member Kristin Forbes: investors 'too sanguine' about Spanish bond risks

Kristin Forbes has suggested that some investors are 'too sanguine' about the risks from countries such as Spain.

Asked by Treasury committee member David Ruffley MP about her concerns about risk pricing in the markets, Forbes pointed out that Spanish 10-year bonds are now trading at the same risk premium as UK 10-year gilts.

She says:

That, to me, suggests that something's not quite right, and that some investors are too sanguine about the risks to Spain.

She's right about the headline numbers (UK 10-year gilts are trading at 2.74%, Spain's 10-year bonds are at 2.76%).

But caution is needed with these comparisons - Spain's debt is in euros, in a currency union where inflation and growth rates are much lower [making sovereign debt more attractive], and with the ECB preparing to ease monetary policy further (even QE, perhaps)

It's not apples and apples, basically.

And one bond yield doesn't give a full assessment of risk premium (although that 10-year gilt yield is a decent benchmark).

Still, Forbes's broader point is that investors are taking risks in a search for yield; a serious issue today.

And that was the end of the hearing:

Updated at 4.35pm BST

3.42pm BST

Forbes also reveals that she's frustrated by the quality of UK data related to investment and trade:

3.40pm BST

Asked about 'forbearance' (whether banks hold off from repossessing a house on a mortgage in arrears), Forbes says she doesn't know exactly how banks will act when rates rise, but monetary policy can't be set based on "risks to small number of highly indebted Britons".

Updated at 4.21pm BST

3.38pm BST

The Treasury committee ask why the Bank of England (like many major central banks) is targeting a 2% inflation rate.

Kristen Forbes reveals that she's asked the BoE this very question -- and the answer is usually that academic papers have suggested it's a sensible level to aim for....

3.34pm BST

Will Kristen Forbes relocate full-time to the UK when she joins the Bank of England?

She explains that she'd hoped to move this summer, but is now planning to commute back and forth from Boston for the first 12 months (spending weekends in the US). She cites her partners' work commitments and getting their child into private schools.

How will you make a living?

Forbes points out that she'll be paid by the Bank of England - she will give some lectures back in the US, but mainly she'll be carrying out her MPC responsibilities here.

3.30pm BST

3.28pm BST

Forbes also gets a real googly - explaining Mark Carney's forward guidance.

She explains (at some length) that it hinges around key data (such as spare capacity), and a pledge that interest rates won't increase until the Bank has clear evidence that the economy is ready.

Committee chairman Andrew Tyrie jokes that he thought it was a trick question.

3.26pm BST

Some Treasury Committee members are suggesting that it would make more sense for the Bank of England to target nominal GDP (ie, the growth rate plus the inflation rate).

Kristen Forbes replies that inflation rate targeting works better (not everyone is convinced) - also, it's the government's job to set the mandate, and the Bank's job to carry it out.

3.22pm BST

The Treasury committee are probing whether Kristen Forbes has the experience for the MPC.

They establishing that she's never held a job in the UK (Forbes explains that she's worked internationally, including several visits to the UK).

Has she ever worked specifically on monetary policy?

Forbes explains that she's worked extensively on macroeconomics – covering issues such as global capital flows and the contagion that is created when shocks occur around the world (everyone remembers the eurozone crisis, right? -- and just look at the impact of the Iraq insurgency on the oil price).

Aren't these issues for the Financial Policy Committee?

No, Forbes says. These are precisely the issues that the MPC needs when setting monetary policy, she argues - and having a range of skills increases the chances they'll get interest rate levels right.

3.17pm BST

Asked whether the MPC's mandate should change, Forbes argues that inflation targeting has done "very well", as a policy goal across the business cycle.

3.10pm BST

On interest rate policies, Kristen Forbes echoes the tone of this morning's Bank of England minutes.

She says that delaying adjusting monetary policy while policymakers await more information runs the risk of needing sharper adjustments in future. So starting tightening monetary policy earlier would offer more flexibility, if need.

But... an earlier adjustment to monetary policy also increases the risk of slowing the recovery, if it's premature.

2.56pm BST

Kristen Forbes begins appearance to parliament about Bank of England appointment

Back in London, Kristen Forbes - one of two female economists who joins the Bank of England this summer - is testifying to parliament's Treasury committee.

Here's a live feed.

Reuters provides the key points so far:

  • BANK OF ENGLAND INCOMING MPC MEMBER KRISTIN FORBES SAYS PRODUCTIVITY GROWTH HAS BEEN UNUSUALLY WEAK, ESPECIALLY FOR A RECOVERY
  • BOE'S FORBES SAYS DECLINE IN UK SAVINGS RATE CANNOT BE SUSTAINED WITHOUT PRESENTING MAJOR RISKS
  • BOE'S FORBES SAYS ANY INCREASE IN ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY COULD QUICKLY CAUSE BUSINESSES TO DELAY BUSINESS INVESTMENT
  • BOE'S FORBES SAYS FULLY APPRECIATE I STILL HAVE MUCH TO LEARN ABOUT THE UK ECONOMIC SITUATION
  • BOE'S FORBES SAYS UNCLEAR IF CURRENT SOURCES OF GROWTH AND EMPLOYMENT GAINS ARE SUSTAINABLE
  • BOE'S FORBES SAYS MPC MUST STILL MONITOR HOUSING MARKET TO ASSESS IF FPC HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN ADDRESSING FINANCIAL STABILITY CONCERNS
  • BOE'S FORBES SAYS DOES NOT BELIEVE ASSET PRICES SHOULD BE TARGETTED, BUT MONITORED

Kristen Forbes is currently professor of management and global economics at MIT's Sloan School of Management, having previously served as an advisor to the White House. She's also an expert in financial market contagion.

Updated at 5.02pm BST

2.49pm BST

Tech stocks are making the early running in New York.

Shares in Adobe Systems have jumped 9% after reporting a bigger-than-expected rise in new subscriptions to its cloud-based services.

And Amazon shares have risen 1.5% - it's expected to announce its first smartphone later today.

2.35pm BST

Ding ding ding - that's the noise of the Wall Street opening bell being rung, and shares are now doing, well, not a lot.

The Dow Jones industrial average has dipped by just 0.1% to 16791 points, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 both flattish too.

Traders are waiting to learn what the Fed's Open Market Committee has decided, and then Janet Yellen's press conference....

2.29pm BST

The Fed is already trying to drum up an audience for Janet Yellen's press conference, even though it doesn't start for five hours:

2.24pm BST

1.59pm BST

Here's something for the Federal Reserve to ponder at today's meeting: the US current account deficit has widened sharply.

The gap between US imports and exports (covering goods, investments and services) swelled to $111.2bn in the first quarter of this year, the US Commerce Department reported. That's the biggest in 18 months, Reuters says.

It appears that America's bad winter drove the trade gap wider, as factories found it harder to produce and ship goods abroad during the most icy weather in some time.

Exports fell by 1.3% during the quarter, while imports rose by 1.5%.

Updated at 2.00pm BST

1.43pm BST

Joao Monteiro, analyst at Valutrades, says the looming Federal Reserve meeting means Wall Street will be rather "subdued":

Futures markets have already called the open as flat and there's very little in the way of fundamentals due ahead of the bell to provide any real influence here.

Obviously any change in the Iraqi situation could inject a degree of volatility but for now we're calling the DOW to open down 2 at 16806 and the S&P up 1 at 1943.

That could change once the second most powerful woman in the world (says Forbes) gives her insight into the US economy and monetary policy.

1.33pm BST

1.30pm BST

Coming up later: The Fed

So, one central bank down, one to go. And it's the biggie later today – the US Federal Reserve announcing its latest monetary policy decisions, followed by a press conference with Fed chair Janet Yellen.

Economists don't expect any real shocks -- the Fed is expected to cut its stimulus programme (buying up US Treasuries and mortgage-backed bonds with new money) by $10bn, to $35bn per month.

But Wall Street (and beyond) will be listening to hear what Yellen says about the future path of interest rates.

The Fed will also issue new economic forecasts; with great timing, we learned yesterday that the US inflation rate had risen faster than expected, to an annual rate of 2.1% in May.

That has "spiced up" the FOMC meeting, says Kit Juckes of Societe Generale.

The trend has been up for a while and the risk of deflation, still prevalent in Europe, just isn't there in the US at the moment.

With inflation at a tolerable level, it's easier to see how out of line Fed policy is with the underlying growth rate of the economy.

The announcement comes at 2pm New York time, or 7pm London, with Yellen's press conference starting 30 minutes later....

Updated at 5.44pm BST

1.10pm BST

Bank of England minutes - a recap

The pound has fallen back from its five-year highs, to $1.695 against the US dollar, as investors calculate that today's Bank of England minutes are less hawkish than expected -- with members voting 9-0 to leave interest rates unchanged.

Economists are split over when rates will rise, after digesting a set of minutes that show widening splits at the BoE over the amount of spare capacity in the labour market.

Some believe borrowing costs will jump this year, such as Alastair Winter of Daniel Stewart Securities, who said

The first interest rate increase will have to be in November or December to avoid the MPC looking foolish over forward guidance.

Others are less sure, pointing to the lack of price pressures at present. As Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, put it:

The very benign outlook for inflation makes it far from a given.

Three key point stand out in the minutes

1) that the decision on when to raise rates is 'more balanced' for some members of the MPC.

2) the committee is struggling to guess how much spare capacity is left -- how to reconcile strong economic growth and falling unemployment with weak inflation and low wage growth

3) The MPC had the nerve to say it was 'surprised' that markets had felt there was little chance of an interest rate rise this year. That sent eyebrows soaring in the City, given governor Mark Carney's regular pronouncements on forward guidance.

Christian Schulz, senior economist at Berenberg bank, nailed it thus:

That is almost ironic given how much Mark Carney and the other MPC members had done until last week’s Mansion House speech to convince markets that any rate hike was still a very long way off, even when the evidence of sizeable slack in the economy started evaporating at ever faster rates on a monthly basis.

Angela Monaghan's news story on the minutes is here:

Interest rate rises: Bank of England minutes hint at shift of stance

Updated at 1.12pm BST

12.49pm BST

Eimear Daly, head of market analysis at Monex Europe, reckons at least one member of the MPC will break ranks and vote for a rate rise soon.

She writes:

“The Bank of England reiterated that rate rises would be slow and gradual, but even it couldn’t deny that the future rate would move in line with economic developments.

MPC members now see the gaining pace of the UK recovery as undeniable, even unstoppable, and are second-guessing their view of economic slack evident in low inflation and wage pressures.

“The Bank has issued a blatant warning sign to markets that there could well be a rate rise this year and it seems more likely than ever that the first vote for higher interest rates is just around the corner.”

12.38pm BST

A speech from Martin Weale, a hawkish member of the Monetary Policy Committee, just landed.

And it doesn't sound quite as hawkish as one might expect, from a man that some City experts thought might have voted for a rate hike this month.

Speaking in Belfast, Weale does make the point that if the Bank is committed to "gradually" raising rates then it should start "sooner than would otherwise be the case."

And Weale adds that that the decision on raising rates is "becoming more balanced, with two opposing forces of uncertain magnitude pushing in different directions."

On the one hand -- the idea that existing measures of underemployment may be overstating the underlying amount of spare capacity in the labour market.

On the other -- a continuing and unusual weakness in wages, which may indicate there is more spare capacity in the economy than the MPC has assumed.

As Weale puts it:

“Should wage growth fail to revive, that will, on its own, tip the scales further in favour of maintaining a strong monetary stimulus.”

However, he also predicts that annual wage growth will reach the range 2.5% to 3% by the end of this year -- enough to justify higher rates?

The speech is here.

Updated at 12.48pm BST

11.32am BST

There's something "almost ironic" in the Bank of England saying it was "surprised" that the financial markets were suggesting a 2014 rate rise was so unlikely.

So says Christian Schulz, senior economist at Berenberg bank, pointing out that the Bank has spent most of the last year pushing Mark Carney's precious forward guidance, that the UK labour market remains too weak to support higher rates.

Schulz reckons rates will probably rise by November, despite the current low inflation. Here's why:

The pressure on the BoE to hike rates immediately remains subdued as long as actual inflation remains below target and wage growth remains weak. But these are lagging the economic cycle and currently distorted by temporary effects like the late Easter, tax changes last year and appreciating sterling.

We expect the unease with easy money amongst the more hawkish spectrum of BoE policy makers to grow and lead to the first individual votes for a hike, potentially this summer. A majority for a first hike should be achieved in November this year.

Updated at 11.43am BST

11.11am BST

Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, has summed up the Bank's minutes:

“A more dovish tone than the surprisingly hawkish views on interest rates presented by Mark Carney in his Mansion House speech is evident, which raises questions about the governor’s apparent shift in thinking.

“That said, the minutes do provide some answers. The Committee noted that the low probability attached by the markets for a rate hike in 2014 was “somewhat surprising”. Moreover, June’s minutes, as well as May’s, pointed to the policy decision becoming “more balanced” for some members.

“While today’s minutes hint that a rate rise could come earlier than 2015, the case for hiking rates soon is far from cut and dried. Yesterday’s inflation figures, which the MPC would not have had sight of, will reinforce the notion that inflation is not causing policy-makers any problems. Indeed, the MPC chose to revise down its expectation for inflation in Q2. The Committee also noted that underlying global weakness in inflationary pressures “might yet become evident in the UK”. And the possibility that labour supply might be stronger than expected was also mooted, pointing to continuing weak wage growth.

“While the Committee has acted in unison since 2011, there is an increasing probability that the single voice of the MPC will soon fracture. The changing make-up of the MPC, with three new members in place by August, could be the catalyst for a shift in thinking. The chances that 2014 will see the first hike in Bank Rate in six years may seem to be on the rise, but the very benign outlook for inflation makes it far from a given.”

11.03am BST

Alastair Winter, chief economist at Daniel Stewart Securities, reckons the Bank of England start raise interest rates before the end of the year, but only gradually.

"The first interest rate increase will have to be in November or December to avoid the MPC looking foolish over forward guidance.

Carney is trading doing an early 1st or 2nd increase against going too fast .

I don't think rates will get to 3% until early 2017 which will still be high enough to encourage companies to borrow and people to feel comfortable servicing their mortgages."

10.55am BST

The minutes show the MPC is "increasingly divided about the appropriate time for tightening", says Nick Beecroft, senior market analyst at Saxo Capital Markets.

Thus Mark Carney's warning during his Mansion House speech that rates could rise faster than markets expect (ed).

“In short, the supertanker is slowing turning towards a tightening bias, and the Governor was keen to prepare us for this last week.”

Updated at 10.55am BST

10.25am BST

The minutes are not the 'hawkish' surprise that some in the markets were predicting, says World First's Jeremy Cook.

He reckons the crucial point in the minutes is that "the precise timing" of a rise would depend on the outlook for inflation (which fell last month). And thus, wage rises.

“In short, the Bank of England is unable to forecast our look for rate increases at the moment and, as we have been tub-thumping for a while, this will depend on real wage increases.

And with inflation still rising twice as fast as wages, there's still plenty of slack in the system, he suggests.

10.20am BST

Jake Trask, corporate dealer at UKForex, reckons the minutes show that UK interest rates probably won't rise until next year.

“Anyone expecting a surprise split vote for a rate rise were left disappointed by the release of the MPC minutes, which showed another 9-0 vote against increasing borrowing costs.

Speculation had been growing since Mark Carney’s bullish comments last week at Mansion House that MPC member Martin Weale might have voted for a rate rise in the 4-5th June meeting; however, this was proved incorrect.

It still looks like a rate rise will be a 2015 event, although, should the run of strong UK data continue, there is a chance that a rate rise may happen around the time of the November Inflation Report.”

10.16am BST

10.08am BST

The pound has fallen back against the US dollar as the City digests the minutes, losing half a cent to $1.695.

The fact that the MPC remained united to leave rates unchanged has dampened speculation of an early rate-- even though some members are wavering...

Updated at 10.09am BST

10.04am BST

Some more instant reaction:

10.02am BST

The Monetary Policy Committee is rather split over how much slack remains in the UK labour market -- which is one key factor in deciding when rates rise.

And the weak growth in earnings is a concern, given the pace of economic growth.

On the 'spare capacity' question, the minute say:

On the one hand, output growth had been stronger, and unemployment had fallen faster, than had been anticipated by the MPC and most other forecasters. On the other hand, wage growth and inflation had been weaker.

One possible explanation was that the effective labour supply was greater than previously thought.

This means wage growth, and its impact on prices, becomes crucial to when rates rise.

9.51am BST

Another interesting line from the BoE minutes -- the MPC discussed whether rates should start rising soon, if they will ultimately peak at a historically low level:

...it could be argued that the more gradual the intended rise in Bank Rate, the earlier it might be necessary to start tightening policy.

However, if you raise too early, you risk wiping out potential output - and it's rather hard to cut rates again if it goes wrong.

9.48am BST

The minutes also include this gem - that the Bank of England is surprised by the financial markets didn't think interest rates were likely to rise this year:

There was, however, a risk that growth would not slow in the second half of the year so that, without a corresponding rise in supply, slack would be absorbed more quickly than had previously been expected.

In that context, the relatively low probability attached to a Bank Rate increase this year implied by some financial market prices was somewhat surprising.

It's almost as if they'd been listening to Mark Carney's forward guidance, that rates would probably remain at their record low for some time.

9.41am BST

9.38am BST

Some Bank of England policymakers have moved closer to voting for an interest rate rise, although the final vote at this month's meeting was 9-0 to leave them unchanged.

The minutes explain that "some" of the nine members of the Monetary Policy Commitee believe the question of whether enough spare capacity has been absorbed has become "more balanced" since May.

Here's the key section:

The economy was starting to return to normal. Part of that normalisation would be a rise in Bank Rate at some point. The precise timing of the rise would depend on the outlook for inflation. That, in turn, would depend on the data flow, and in particular what that implied for the degree of slack, the prospects for its absorption, and the broader outlook for wages.

For some members, the policy decision had become more balanced in the past couple of months than earlier in the year. In terms of the immediate policy decision, however, all members agreed that, in the absence of other inflationary pressures, it would be necessary to see more evidence of slack being absorbed before an increase in Bank Rate would be warranted.

The minutes are online here.

Updated at 9.40am BST

9.31am BST

Bank of England MPC voted 9-0 to leave rates unchanged

Here we go: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted 9-0 to leave interest rates at their record low of 0.5%, at its meeting two weeks ago.

The minutes, just released, also show that the Bank was "somewhat surprised" that the financial markets were pricing in a low probability of interest rates rising this year.

More to follow!

9.20am BST

Just 10 minutes until the Bank of England reveals whether there was heated debate at its last monetary policy committee meeting....

Updated at 9.20am BST

9.19am BST

A couple of developments between Britain and China this morning.

1) China Construction Bank (CCB) has been named as London's first bank to act as a clearing bank for the Chinese renminbi (RMB) -- the first renminbi clearing bank outside Asia. The Treasury says it is

...part of the government’s long-term economic plan to establish Britain as the western hub of Chinese finance.

2) China's central bank has announced that the yuan will start trading directly against sterling in the interbank foreign exchange market, from Thursday. That's also billed as a move to strengthen trade links between the two countries.

Updated at 9.26am BST

8.58am BST

City traders are reporting that Cyprus is on track to sell its first sovereign debt in a public auction* since last year's bailout.

It's offering a five-year bond this morning, at an interest rate of 5% -- not too shabby, given its recent troubles.

* - Cyprus sold some debt to one private investor recently, but this is the first time it's actually gone to the markets to borrow since the dramatic days of March 2013

8.53am BST

Back on the Bank of England, and Jeremy Cook of World First reckons today's minutes may show sharp differences over how much spare capacity is lingering in UK labour market:

Today’s minutes will be raked through for potentially hawkish clues to back up the deviation in the Governor’s language from his first year at the head of the Bank of England. The obvious place for differing views is within the unemployment market, such is the nature of the Bank’s forward guidance plan.

While the overall unemployment rate is below the original 7% level that was used as a waypoint for rate rises, the issue of slack in the economy has taken over. Carney estimated that overall slack in the jobs market was somewhere between 1-1.5% at last month’s Quarterly Inflation Report; we’ll see how much of a consensus that view is.

There could also have been a lively debate about real wage growth (or the lack of it). More in this video clip:

8.46am BST

In other corporate news, property website Zoopla priced its stock market flotation at the lower end of its guidance today - perhaps a sign that speculation of an early interest rate rise hit demand?

The offer price was set 220p - having previously set a range of 200p-250p. That values the firm, whose sites include Primelocation, at £919m.

8.33am BST

Are we all eating less Ambrosia custard and Batchelors Soup? What about Mr Kipling's cakes?

Premier Foods warned that sales of its 'Power Brands' have unexpectedly fallen in the second quarter of this year, blaming "subdued grocery markets".

Shares in the company promptly tumbled by 6.5% - not exceedingly good news for investors.

It's another sign that the supermarket sector is getting tight (yesterday's inflation data showed the first fall in food prices in almost a decade).

And here are those 'Power Brands' in full:

8.25am BST

The other development in Argentina overnight (apart from the S&P downgrade) is that it is taking steps to swap 'restructured' bonds, to place them under Argentinian law.

This could allow Argentina to get around Monday's US Supreme Court defeat. It could then keep making payments to creditors who helped it lower its debt burden after the 2001 default, rather than the 'holdout' hedge funds who want paying in full.

As economy minister Axel Kicillof put it:

We cannot allow (holdouts) to prevent us from honoring our commitments to creditors."

But such a move could also move Argentina closer to defaulting - as it would no longer be meeting the terms of the original bonds.

Chris Weston of IG points out that the cost of insuring its debt (using a credit default swap, or CDS) has risen to a five-month high.

Yesterday’s speech by the economy minister to congress that the government plans to swap exchange bonds into Argentine law seems significant.

Many feel this puts them on a path for default and we should see this in today’s session, with further selling of Argentine bonds, while the CDS premium should continue to spike.

8.04am BST

Minutes: what the analyst predict

Kit Juckes of Societe Generale reckons the MPC minutes will be "fascinating" – why else did governor Carney shock the markets by hinting at a rate rise last Thursday night?

Surely there was something in the meeting to get Mr Carmey to be so bold at the Mansion House.

I mean, he wan't really going for headlines at the start of Brazil/Croatia, was he? With inflation down, the stakes go up.

Juckes reckons UK interest rates are too low, given the economy is growing at 3% per year, so "the splits in the MPC are likely to widen".

Ian Williamson of Peel Hunt hopes the minutes will explain why Carney hinted at an early rate rise, only for yesterday's inflation data to be weaker than expected (at just 1.5%)

He says:

May's UK CPI data only added to the puzzlement surrounding the more hawkish message delivered by Governor Carney last week, although the causes of that change of heart may become clearer after today's MPC minutes.

Updated at 8.05am BST

7.48am BST

All eyes on the Bank of England minutes....

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business.

How close is the Bank of England, really, to gritting its teeth and raising interest rates?

There's been a lot of talk, from governor Mark Carney downwards, but this morning we see whether anyone on the Monetary Policy Committee actually wants some action.

The minutes of the MPC meeting a fortnight ago, released at 9.30am, will show whether any members broke the 9-0 voting consensus and pushed for a hike (unlikely), and also show if the wider committee thinks it's almost time to start hiking (more likely).

Carney's hawkish Mansion House speech last week has changed the agenda; Monex Europe's analyst Eimear Daly reckons the minutes will be pretty interesting:

Elsewhere, pressure continues to build on Argentina, after losing its court case against hedge funds pushing for debt issued before its 2001 default to be honoured in full.

Overnight, S&P slashed its credit rating to just CCC-, citing a higher risk of default, now that Buenos Aires has been ordered to repay those bonds alongside its restructured debt - something president Fernandez continues to resist.

While in the eurozone, some Greek public health workers are holding a strikes; and Cyprus is expected to hold a public bond auction - a milestone in its bailout programme.

And the markets are likely to be edgy ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting tonight, where the US central bank is expected to trim its stimulus programme again.

We'll be tracking the main action through the day....

Updated at 9.07am BST

The Federal Open Markets Committee announces, as expected, that it is continuing to wind down, or "taper" its bond-buying program known as quantitative easing. Here's Guardian US economics editor Heidi Moore's primer on what to expect from Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen's 2pm press conference. This meeting will be the one where the Federal Reserve will have to prove it's connected to reality. Its forecasts have been relatively chipper - or at least optimistic - through five years of a slow recovery. Now the tides seem be turning, and the recovery looks threatened. As Lindsey Group analyst Peter Boockvar wrote to clients today, "their credibility is on the line if they ignore that the facts are now different." What facts? Here's what observers are watching. GDP: Expect the Fed to cut its estimates. The Fed's estimates for GDP - which measures the overall productivity of the economy - were on the high side for 2014, with expectations of 2.8% to 3% growth. The actual latest growth figure is far, far below that: it's -1%. Being off by a few percentage points is a big issue for the Fed's credibility -- though to be fair, it's used to being wrong. Still, look for the Fed to join the reality-based community by cutting its forecasts for economic growth. Unemployment: Expect the Fed to cut its estimates. The Fed most recently expected the unemployment rate to fall to the range of 6.1 to 6.3% by the end of the year. It's already there, as Boockvar notes, with two straight months of 6.3% unemployment. but it doesn't tell the whole story. The reason the unemployment rate is falling is because more people are becoming disillusioned and dropping out of the workforce. The best measure of that dropout trend is called the the labor force participation rate, and it measures how many working-age adults actually have jobs. At the moment, it's 62.8% - one of the lowest percentages in 30 years. Inflation: Watch how the Fed interprets the data. After years of bafflement over why inflation remained so low, inflation is rising for consumers far faster than the Fed expected. The real-world measure of inflation, which is called the Consumer Price Index or CPI, is now at about 2% - far above the 1.7% that the Fed predicted in April. Housing: Watch how the Fed interprets the data. The housing market has been struggling more than the Fed expected, with expert Robert Shiller calling the trends "worrisome." The rise in housing prices is supposed to make consumers feel rich enough to spend more money, but it's not accomplishing that. "The spring home selling season has been mixed at best as investors have slowed down their purchase pace and the first time potential home buyer has been more inclined to rent," Boockvar wrote. Interest rates: The Federal Reserve's job is to manage interest rates, and investors have been waiting years for an increase in rates; they argue that low rates have been hurting savings. The Fed has indicated it won't raise interest rates until 2015 or later. With the economic picture worsening, however, it may be under pressure. Overall: Expect a "nothing to see here, folks," stance that will require a deeper interpretation of how the Fed is seeing the economy. She cites her partners' work commitments and getting their child into private schools. How will you make a living? Forbes points out that she'll be paid by the Bank of England - she will give some lectures back in the US, but mainly she'll be carrying out her MPC responsibilities here. Committee chairman Andrew Tyrie jokes that he thought it was a trick question. Some Treasury Committee members are suggesting that it would make more sense for the Bank of England to target nominal GDP (ie, the growth rate plus the inflation rate). Kristen Forbes replies that inflation rate targeting works better (not everyone is convinced) - also, it's the government's job to set the mandate, and the Bank's job to carry it out. The Treasury committee are probing whether Kristen Forbes has the experience for the MPC. They establishing that she's never held a job in the UK (Forbes explains that she's worked internationally, including several visits to the UK). Has she ever worked specifically on monetary policy? Forbes explains that she's worked extensively on macroeconomics – covering issues such as global capital flows and the contagion that is created when shocks occur around the world (everyone remembers the eurozone crisis, right? -- and just look at the impact of the Iraq insurgency on the oil price). Asked whether the MPC's mandate should change, Forbes argues that inflation targeting has done "very well", as a policy goal across the business cycle. She says that delaying adjusting monetary policy while policymakers await more information runs the risk of needing sharper adjustments in future. But... an earlier adjustment to monetary policy also increases the risk of slowing the recovery, if it's premature. Back in London, Kristen Forbes - one of two female economists who joins the Bank of England this summer - is testifying to parliament's Treasury committee. Here's a live feed. Reuters provides the key points so far: BANK OF ENGLAND INCOMING MPC MEMBER KRISTIN FORBES SAYS PRODUCTIVITY GROWTH HAS BEEN UNUSUALLY WEAK, ESPECIALLY FOR A RECOVERY BOE'S FORBES SAYS DECLINE IN UK SAVINGS RATE CANNOT BE SUSTAINED WITHOUT PRESENTING MAJOR RISKS BOE'S FORBES SAYS ANY INCREASE IN ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY COULD QUICKLY CAUSE BUSINESSES TO DELAY BUSINESS INVESTMENT BOE'S FORBES SAYS FULLY APPRECIATE I STILL HAVE MUCH TO LEARN ABOUT THE UK ECONOMIC SITUATION BOE'S FORBES SAYS UNCLEAR IF CURRENT SOURCES OF GROWTH AND EMPLOYMENT GAINS ARE SUSTAINABLE BOE'S FORBES SAYS MPC MUST STILL MONITOR HOUSING MARKET TO ASSESS IF FPC HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN ADDRESSING FINANCIAL STABILITY CONCERNS BOE'S FORBES SAYS DOES NOT BELIEVE ASSET PRICES SHOULD BE TARGETTED, BUT MONITORED Kristen Forbes is currently professor of management and global economics at MIT's Sloan School of Management, having previously served as an advisor to the White House. She's also an expert in financial market contagion. Tech stocks are making the early running in New York. Shares in Adobe Systems have jumped 9% after reporting a bigger-than-expected rise in new subscriptions to its cloud-based services. And Amazon shares have risen 1.5% - it's expected to announce its first smartphone later today. Ding ding ding - that's the noise of the Wall Street opening bell being rung, and shares are now doing, well, not a lot. The Dow Jones industrial average has dipped by just 0.1% to 16791 points, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 both flattish too. Traders are waiting to learn what the Fed's Open Market Committee has decided, and then Janet Yellen's press conference.... The Fed is already trying to drum up an audience for Janet Yellen's press conference, even though it doesn't start for five hours: Here's something for the Federal Reserve to ponder at today's meeting: the US current account deficit has widened sharply. The gap between US imports and exports (covering goods, investments and services) swelled to $111.2bn in the first quarter of this year, the US Commerce Department reported. That's the biggest in 18 months, Reuters says. It appears that America's bad winter drove the trade gap wider, as factories found it harder to produce and ship goods abroad during the most icy weather in some time. Exports fell by 1.3% during the quarter, while imports rose by 1.5%. Joao Monteiro, analyst at Valutrades, says the looming Federal Reserve meeting means Wall Street will be rather "subdued": Futures markets have already called the open as flat and there's very little in the way of fundamentals due ahead of the bell to provide any real influence here. Obviously any change in the Iraqi situation could inject a degree of volatility but for now we're calling the DOW to open down 2 at 16806 and the S&P up 1 at 1943. That could change once the second most powerful woman in the world (says Forbes) gives her insight into the US economy and monetary policy. So, one central bank down, one to go. And it's the biggie later today – the US Federal Reserve announcing its latest monetary policy decisions, followed by a press conference with Fed chair Janet Yellen. Economists don't expect any real shocks -- the Fed is expected to cut its stimulus programme (buying up US Treasuries and mortgage-backed bonds with new money) by $10bn, to $35bn per month. But Wall Street (and beyond) will be listening to hear what Yellen says about the future path of interest rates. The Fed will also issue new economic forecasts; with great timing, we learned yesterday that the US inflation rate had risen faster than expected, to an annual rate of 2.1% in May. That has "spiced up" the FOMC meeting, says Kit Juckes of Societe Generale. The trend has been up for a while and the risk of deflation, still prevalent in Europe, just isn't there in the US at the moment. With inflation at a tolerable level, it's easier to see how out of line Fed policy is with the underlying growth rate of the economy. The announcement comes at 2pm New York time, or 7pm London, with Yellen's press conference starting 30 minutes later.... The pound has fallen back from its five-year highs, to $1.695 against the US dollar, as investors calculate that today's Bank of England minutes are less hawkish than expected -- with members voting 9-0 to leave interest rates unchanged. Economists are split over when rates will rise, after digesting a set of minutes that show widening splits at the BoE over the amount of spare capacity in the labour market. Some believe borrowing costs will jump this year, such as Alastair Winter of Daniel Stewart Securities, who said The first interest rate increase will have to be in November or December to avoid the MPC looking foolish over forward guidance. Others are less sure, pointing to the lack of price pressures at present. As Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, put it: The very benign outlook for inflation makes it far from a given. Three key point stand out in the minutes 1) that the decision on when to raise rates is 'more balanced' for some members of the MPC. 2) the committee is struggling to guess how much spare capacity is left -- how to reconcile strong economic growth and falling unemployment with weak inflation and low wage growth 3) The MPC had the nerve to say it was 'surprised' that markets had felt there was little chance of an interest rate rise this year. That sent eyebrows soaring in the City, given governor Mark Carney's regular pronouncements on forward guidance. Christian Schulz, senior economist at Berenberg bank, nailed it thus: That is almost ironic given how much Mark Carney and the other MPC members had done until last week’s Mansion House speech to convince markets that any rate hike was still a very long way off, even when the evidence of sizeable slack in the economy started evaporating at ever faster rates on a monthly basis. Angela Monaghan's news story on the minutes is here: Interest rate rises: Bank of England minutes hint at shift of stance Eimear Daly, head of market analysis at Monex Europe, reckons at least one member of the MPC will break ranks and vote for a rate rise soon. She writes: “The Bank of England reiterated that rate rises would be slow and gradual, but even it couldn’t deny that the future rate would move in line with economic developments. MPC members now see the gaining pace of the UK recovery as undeniable, even unstoppable, and are second-guessing their view of economic slack evident in low inflation and wage pressures. “The Bank has issued a blatant warning sign to markets that there could well be a rate rise this year and it seems more likely than ever that the first vote for higher interest rates is just around the corner.” A speech from Martin Weale, a hawkish member of the Monetary Policy Committee, just landed. And it doesn't sound quite as hawkish as one might expect, from a man that some City experts thought might have voted for a rate hike this month. Speaking in Belfast, Weale does make the point that if the Bank is committed to "gradually" raising rates then it should start "sooner than would otherwise be the case." And Weale adds that that the decision on raising rates is "becoming more balanced, with two opposing forces of uncertain magnitude pushing in different directions." On the one hand -- the idea that existing measures of underemployment may be overstating the underlying amount of spare capacity in the labour market. On the other -- a continuing and unusual weakness in wages, which may indicate there is more spare capacity in the economy than the MPC has assumed. As Weale puts it: “Should wage growth fail to revive, that will, on its own, tip the scales further in favour of maintaining a strong monetary stimulus.” However, he also predicts that annual wage growth will reach the range 2.5% to 3% by the end of this year -- enough to justify higher rates? The speech is here. There's something "almost ironic" in the Bank of England saying it was "surprised" that the financial markets were suggesting a 2014 rate rise was so unlikely. So says Christian Schulz, senior economist at Berenberg bank, pointing out that the Bank has spent most of the last year pushing Mark Carney's precious forward guidance, that the UK labour market remains too weak to support higher rates. Schulz reckons rates will probably rise by November, despite the current low inflation. Here's why: The pressure on the BoE to hike rates immediately remains subdued as long as actual inflation remains below target and wage growth remains weak. But these are lagging the economic cycle and currently distorted by temporary effects like the late Easter, tax changes last year and appreciating sterling. We expect the unease with easy money amongst the more hawkish spectrum of BoE policy makers to grow and lead to the first individual votes for a hike, potentially this summer. A majority for a first hike should be achieved in November this year. Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, has summed up the Bank's minutes: “A more dovish tone than the surprisingly hawkish views on interest rates presented by Mark Carney in his Mansion House speech is evident, which raises questions about the governor’s apparent shift in thinking. “That said, the minutes do provide some answers. The Committee noted that the low probability attached by the markets for a rate hike in 2014 was “somewhat surprising”. Moreover, June’s minutes, as well as May’s, pointed to the policy decision becoming “more balanced” for some members. “While today’s minutes hint that a rate rise could come earlier than 2015, the case for hiking rates soon is far from cut and dried. Yesterday’s inflation figures, which the MPC would not have had sight of, will reinforce the notion that inflation is not causing policy-makers any problems. Indeed, the MPC chose to revise down its expectation for inflation in Q2. The Committee also noted that underlying global weakness in inflationary pressures “might yet become evident in the UK”. And the possibility that labour supply might be stronger than expected was also mooted, pointing to continuing weak wage growth. “While the Committee has acted in unison since 2011, there is an increasing probability that the single voice of the MPC will soon fracture. The changing make-up of the MPC, with three new members in place by August, could be the catalyst for a shift in thinking. The chances that 2014 will see the first hike in Bank Rate in six years may seem to be on the rise, but the very benign outlook for inflation makes it far from a given.” Alastair Winter, chief economist at Daniel Stewart Securities, reckons the Bank of England start raise interest rates before the end of the year, but only gradually. "The first interest rate increase will have to be in November or December to avoid the MPC looking foolish over forward guidance. Carney is trading doing an early 1st or 2nd increase against going too fast . I don't think rates will get to 3% until early 2017 which will still be high enough to encourage companies to borrow and people to feel comfortable servicing their mortgages." The minutes show the MPC is "increasingly divided about the appropriate time for tightening", says Nick Beecroft, senior market analyst at Saxo Capital Markets. Thus Mark Carney's warning during his Mansion House speech that rates could rise faster than markets expect (ed). “In short, the supertanker is slowing turning towards a tightening bias, and the Governor was keen to prepare us for this last week.” The minutes are not the 'hawkish' surprise that some in the markets were predicting, says World First's Jeremy Cook. He reckons the crucial point in the minutes is that "the precise timing" of a rise would depend on the outlook for inflation (which fell last month). And thus, wage rises. “In short, the Bank of England is unable to forecast our look for rate increases at the moment and, as we have been tub-thumping for a while, this will depend on real wage increases. And with inflation still rising twice as fast as wages, there's still plenty of slack in the system, he suggests. Jake Trask, corporate dealer at UKForex, reckons the minutes show that UK interest rates probably won't rise until next year. “Anyone expecting a surprise split vote for a rate rise were left disappointed by the release of the MPC minutes, which showed another 9-0 vote against increasing borrowing costs. Speculation had been growing since Mark Carney’s bullish comments last week at Mansion House that MPC member Martin Weale might have voted for a rate rise in the 4-5th June meeting; however, this was proved incorrect. It still looks like a rate rise will be a 2015 event, although, should the run of strong UK data continue, there is a chance that a rate rise may happen around the time of the November Inflation Report.” The pound has fallen back against the US dollar as the City digests the minutes, losing half a cent to $1.695. The fact that the MPC remained united to leave rates unchanged has dampened speculation of an early rate-- even though some members are wavering... Some more instant reaction: The Monetary Policy Committee is rather split over how much slack remains in the UK labour market -- which is one key factor in deciding when rates rise. And the weak growth in earnings is a concern, given the pace of economic growth. On the 'spare capacity' question, the minute say: On the one hand, output growth had been stronger, and unemployment had fallen faster, than had been anticipated by the MPC and most other forecasters. On the other hand, wage growth and inflation had been weaker. One possible explanation was that the effective labour supply was greater than previously thought. This means wage growth, and its impact on prices, becomes crucial to when rates rise. Another interesting line from the BoE minutes -- the MPC discussed whether rates should start rising soon, if they will ultimately peak at a historically low level: ...it could be argued that the more gradual the intended rise in Bank Rate, the earlier it might be necessary to start tightening policy. However, if you raise too early, you risk wiping out potential output - and it's rather hard to cut rates again if it goes wrong. The minutes also include this gem - that the Bank of England is surprised by the financial markets didn't think interest rates were likely to rise this year: There was, however, a risk that growth would not slow in the second half of the year so that, without a corresponding rise in supply, slack would be absorbed more quickly than had previously been expected. In that context, the relatively low probability attached to a Bank Rate increase this year implied by some financial market prices was somewhat surprising. It's almost as if they'd been listening to Mark Carney's forward guidance, that rates would probably remain at their record low for some time. Some Bank of England policymakers have moved closer to voting for an interest rate rise, although the final vote at this month's meeting was 9-0 to leave them unchanged. The minutes explain that "some" of the nine members of the Monetary Policy Commitee believe the question of whether enough spare capacity has been absorbed has become "more balanced" since May. Here's the key section: The economy was starting to return to normal. Part of that normalisation would be a rise in Bank Rate at some point. The precise timing of the rise would depend on the outlook for inflation. That, in turn, would depend on the data flow, and in particular what that implied for the degree of slack, the prospects for its absorption, and the broader outlook for wages. For some members, the policy decision had become more balanced in the past couple of months than earlier in the year. In terms of the immediate policy decision, however, all members agreed that, in the absence of other inflationary pressures, it would be necessary to see more evidence of slack being absorbed before an increase in Bank Rate would be warranted. The minutes are online here. Here we go: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted 9-0 to leave interest rates at their record low of 0.5%, at its meeting two weeks ago. The minutes, just released, also show that the Bank was "somewhat surprised" that the financial markets were pricing in a low probability of interest rates rising this year. More to follow! Just 10 minutes until the Bank of England reveals whether there was heated debate at its last monetary policy committee meeting.... A couple of developments between Britain and China this morning. 1) China Construction Bank (CCB) has been named as London's first bank to act as a clearing bank for the Chinese renminbi (RMB) -- the first renminbi clearing bank outside Asia. The Treasury says it is ...part of the government’s long-term economic plan to establish Britain as the western hub of Chinese finance. 2) China's central bank has announced that the yuan will start trading directly against sterling in the interbank foreign exchange market, from Thursday. That's also billed as a move to strengthen trade links between the two countries. City traders are reporting that Cyprus is on track to sell its first sovereign debt in a public auction* since last year's bailout. It's offering a five-year bond this morning, at an interest rate of 5% -- not too shabby, given its recent troubles. * - Cyprus sold some debt to one private investor recently, but this is the first time it's actually gone to the markets to borrow since the dramatic days of March 2013 Back on the Bank of England, and Jeremy Cook of World First reckons today's minutes may show sharp differences over how much spare capacity is lingering in UK labour market: Today’s minutes will be raked through for potentially hawkish clues to back up the deviation in the Governor’s language from his first year at the head of the Bank of England. The obvious place for differing views is within the unemployment market, such is the nature of the Bank’s forward guidance plan. While the overall unemployment rate is below the original 7% level that was used as a waypoint for rate rises, the issue of slack in the economy has taken over. Carney estimated that overall slack in the jobs market was somewhere between 1-1.5% at last month’s Quarterly Inflation Report; we’ll see how much of a consensus that view is. There could also have been a lively debate about real wage growth (or the lack of it). More in this video clip: In other corporate news, property website Zoopla priced its stock market flotation at the lower end of its guidance today - perhaps a sign that speculation of an early interest rate rise hit demand? The offer price was set 220p - having previously set a range of 200p-250p. That values the firm, whose sites include Primelocation, at £919m. Are we all eating less Ambrosia custard and Batchelors Soup? What about Mr Kipling's cakes? Premier Foods warned that sales of its 'Power Brands' have unexpectedly fallen in the second quarter of this year, blaming "subdued grocery markets". Shares in the company promptly tumbled by 6.5% - not exceedingly good news for investors. It's another sign that the supermarket sector is getting tight (yesterday's inflation data showed the first fall in food prices in almost a decade). And here are those 'Power Brands' in full: The other development in Argentina overnight (apart from the S&P downgrade) is that it is taking steps to swap 'restructured' bonds, to place them under Argentinian law. This could allow Argentina to get around Monday's US Supreme Court defeat. It could then keep making payments to creditors who helped it lower its debt burden after the 2001 default, rather than the 'holdout' hedge funds who want paying in full. As economy minister Axel Kicillof put it: We cannot allow (holdouts) to prevent us from honoring our commitments to creditors." But such a move could also move Argentina closer to defaulting - as it would no longer be meeting the terms of the original bonds. Chris Weston of IG points out that the cost of insuring its debt (using a credit default swap, or CDS) has risen to a five-month high. Yesterday’s speech by the economy minister to congress that the government plans to swap exchange bonds into Argentine law seems significant. Many feel this puts them on a path for default and we should see this in today’s session, with further selling of Argentine bonds, while the CDS premium should continue to spike. Kit Juckes of Societe Generale reckons the MPC minutes will be "fascinating" – why else did governor Carney shock the markets by hinting at a rate rise last Thursday night? Surely there was something in the meeting to get Mr Carmey to be so bold at the Mansion House. I mean, he wan't really going for headlines at the start of Brazil/Croatia, was he? With inflation down, the stakes go up. Juckes reckons UK interest rates are too low, given the economy is growing at 3% per year, so "the splits in the MPC are likely to widen". Ian Williamson of Peel Hunt hopes the minutes will explain why Carney hinted at an early rate rise, only for yesterday's inflation data to be weaker than expected (at just 1.5%) He says: May's UK CPI data only added to the puzzlement surrounding the more hawkish message delivered by Governor Carney last week, although the causes of that change of heart may become clearer after today's MPC minutes. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business. How close is the Bank of England, really, to gritting its teeth and raising interest rates? There's been a lot of talk, from governor Mark Carney downwards, but this morning we see whether anyone on the Monetary Policy Committee actually wants some action. The minutes of the MPC meeting a fortnight ago, released at 9.30am, will show whether any members broke the 9-0 voting consensus and pushed for a hike (unlikely), and also show if the wider committee thinks it's almost time to start hiking (more likely). Carney's hawkish Mansion House speech last week has changed the agenda; Monex Europe's analyst Eimear Daly reckons the minutes will be pretty interesting: Elsewhere, pressure continues to build on Argentina, after losing its court case against hedge funds pushing for debt issued before its 2001 default to be honoured in full. Overnight, S&P slashed its credit rating to just CCC-, citing a higher risk of default, now that Buenos Aires has been ordered to repay those bonds alongside its restructured debt - something president Fernandez continues to resist. While in the eurozone, some Greek public health workers are holding a strikes; and Cyprus is expected to hold a public bond auction - a milestone in its bailout programme. And the markets are likely to be edgy ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting tonight, where the US central bank is expected to trim its stimulus programme again. We'll be tracking the main action through the day....

webTitle: Bank of England's latest interest-rate setting recruit sounds warning

fields.bodyText: The Bank of England's latest interest-rate setting recruit has warned that raising the cost of borrowing without disrupting markets or derailing the UK's economic recovery will be a major challenge. Kristin Forbes, a former economic adviser to George Bush and MIT professor, told MPs on the Treasury select committee that the Bank's monetary policy committee, which she joins next month, must not take markets and households by surprise when the time comes to hoist rates from the current all-time low of 0.5%. "You need to prepare for this, do it gradually," she said. She said monetary policy would be the "last line of defence" on matters of financial stability, including a potential housing bubble. She had "much to learn about the UK economic situation", she said, but insisted she had sufficient experience to take on the role.
